TLDR: This is a really, really fun game but it's lacking severely in content right now. (Yes I get that it's in early access) Buy it on release. 

The final tier for character abilities is still locked out, there's only one map, only a few types of enemies; not much has been added since the demo. Took me around 12 hours to max out everything, and I only have 2-3 achievements remaining, if I'm not mistaken. 

I hope the content is added at a fast rate, will keep checking back in from time to time. 

That said though, this and Greedland have been the two most enjoyable Survivor games (guess it's a genre now) that I've ever played.  However, I still can't give it a thumbs up as I've seen far more content in Early Access titles in the past.

As some have stated the current amount of content is rather on the low side.  It is early access however so this is expected.  The amount of replay-ability is high however which rather negates that complaint.  I have enjoyed all of my time leveling up my characters and sometimes its nice to just destroy zombies moderately mindlessly for hours on end.  Definitely worth it for the price.

[h1]Quickfire Review[/h1]
YAZS is very close to taking the crown away from Vampire Survivors on my top 5 list of bullet hell games.

Nevermind, I lied. It's already at the top of the list from the amount of fun I had with it thus far. The setting, look, and overall feel of the game has so much potential and we've only seen a fraction of what the game has to offer in terms of content. Each class and team/skill combination leaves a sense of curiosity as to how much havoc and rampage I can cause in a variety of ways with no sense of boredom whatsoever. Ghost+Huntress+Engineer with Thousand Cuts->Crit Chance->Blaster->ES? Can't touch me. SWAT+Engineer+Tank with AR->Launcher->Blaster->Mines/Chopper/Sentry? Don't even think about getting close. Don't forget about Happiness +10. Always take Happiness10.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Final Verdict: A+[/b]

Yet Another Zombie Survivors: Exceptional Gameplay Value and Replayability

Overall Score: 9/10

Yet Another Zombie Survivors shines as a captivating blend of roguelite/action roguelike/rpg genres that elegantly balances complexity with exceptional replayability, making it an undeniable gem for its cost.

Gameplay (10/10): Simplicity is king. The game's intuitive and fun mechanics make it an instant hit from the get-go. The controls are refreshingly accessible, and the gameplay loops are rewarding, making every second engaging.

Story and Characters (8/10): While the game isn't narrative-heavy, the variety in the character roster is commendable. Though there's not much room for character development, the variation itself provides ample depth, given the type of game it is.

Graphics and Art Style (8/10): The visual appeal of Yet Another Zombie Survivors adds to the immersive experience. The consistent and distinctive art style, though not groundbreaking, creates a captivating atmosphere perfect for a zombie apocalypse scenario.

Sound and Music (7/10): The soundtrack and sound effects effectively complement the game's overall theme. They may not be spectacular, but they're fitting, enhancing the gaming experience with their appropriate timing and mood setting.

Replayability (10/10): "Yet Another Zombie Survivors" is a treasure trove when it comes to replayability. With countless strategies to experiment with and achievements to unlock, each playthrough feels as fresh and exciting as the last.

Innovation (6/10): While Yet Another Zombie Survivors doesn't introduce groundbreaking mechanics or concepts, it shines in its flawless execution of existing ones. It takes familiar elements from roguelites, action RPGs, and bullet hell games and crafts them into a cohesive, engaging experience.

Value (10/10): Without a doubt, "Yet Another Zombie Survivors" offers tremendous value. The sheer amount of content and endless replayability, coupled with an appealing price point, makes it an exemplary choice for gamers seeking a top-notch gaming experience without breaking the bank.

In conclusion, Yet Another Zombie Survivors is a fun game that consistently challenges and compels you to enhance your strategy. Its focus on engagement and community interaction, evident in the active developer-led Discord and forums, creates a vibrant, immersive gaming ecosystem. If you're hunting for a game that respects your time, investment, and strategic prowess, Yet Another Zombie Survivors is an easy recommendation.

It's clearly early access but I like what I see so far and am happy to support the developer whom seems to be passionate about the project. Will check back in couple of months and play again.

Sadly, even though I wanted to enjoy this, it's a NO for me at the time.

It's too early for this game, the content is scarce, the upgrades most of the time don't feel impactful (read a review that said meta-progress is impactful in this game and thought wow nice) when in the end, it isn't at all, I did 15 min in my first run and after dying and spending some meta points the second one lasted 5 min because I took another less powerful main character.

The squad picking is cool but having only 3 characters to start (4 if you count the one you unlock fast) there really aren't much skills to see and much difference between your runs, at the 3 hour mark I've almost seen all the game has to offer at the moment. 

The game also features just one map at the moment, like man couldn't devs have waited a bit more and release the game with at least 2 or 3 different zones? The first one gets stale pretty fast in my opinion.

Then there's the aiming, oh god the aiming is damn horrible, you will lose countless runs because your characters feel like kids who have never shot a gun, you miss tons of shots while moving and to really get all your bullets to hit you need to stop (good luck with this in a zombie game).

The enemy variety is not bad but you get hit really easy and the feedback for it is not good at all most of the time.

I just think this game needed some more months in the oven before releasing. I'll check it out in some months and change my review accordingly but at the moment I don't think it's worth your time if you're not a Survivor-like diehard fan.

Cool little Vampire Survivors style game that's decent for killing time. Extra price tag comes with better graphics/sound quality and surprisingly few bugs, Only one level at the time of writing this, but there are plenty of challenges and unlocks to earn and 6 different survivor class combos to try out. There are 3 modes, standard 20-minute timed round, endless mode, and a hardcore 10-minute round. Took me roughly 17 hours to 100% the game at the writing of this review, but will still play some just to try out more of the class combos. Looking forward to the additional content down the road.

i have been playing a lot of Vampire Survivor, Hall of Torment and this game these week. So far comparing the three, this game's pace is slower. The skill progression is slower for this game. Needing to kill 5k, 15k and 25k to access the other skill is kinda okay as long as monster density is at par. Ive played a lot for 3 hours and in average you get to kill 5k mobs at 15 minutes. so to unlock ur character's skill u need to rerun the mission 5 times to access all of them Comparing to Vampire Survivors and Halls of Torment, u get to run once and twice to get all the bells and whistles associated to ur character. Also the items. there are a lot, like A LOT. and it feels that it doesnt help in the characters progression. The skills arent balanced for all characters. Medic is the most gimped of the three, then ghost and then hunter. It was more efficient to run Swat, Tank and Engineer at rank 2 as their skills synergize. I got burnt today trying to max rank my swat and i thought id get a better skill or a new weapon. The turrent doesnt have enough power to warrant to level. I dont think i would rank up the rest of the characters if thats what i get killing 25k mobs.  Same as the Training skills. Magnet at max doesnt absorb a lot of area. Xp at max doesnt feel it increases per level u buy. Also, whats with the invulnerable skill. i tried endless horde but when it got to lvl 18, i get hit by the boss ALL the time. the invulerable skill doesnt seem to work and it requires a lot of skill points which is a but tedious to get since the amount increases as the level increase. Why dont we just use the cash we collect from the mission.

All in all, its not a bad game. the pacing of the game is a slow. its fun at the start but the grind can burn you out. A lot of things need to be addressed to be at par with the other games of the same genre. Even brotato is more fun than this.

Games like these arent meant to be grinded. It supposed to be fast paced and fun. I dont feel that with this game.

The game actually looks good and has a cool concept. However, I am not a fan of the fact that you can't actually aim your characters. This forces you to use its auto-aim feature, and it's terrible. I am not going to waste hours into this game only to survive because the AI does not pick the right targets, and honestly, it seems very random as to what it chooses.

I was using the shotgun guy, which has a good spread on the shots, but the AI would constantly look to shoot the zombies solo instead of the massive pack, not utilizing its kit much better. It felt frustrating and counter-intuitive, making the game play less enjoyable.

When I joined the Discord to see how I could disable this feature, I was disappointed to find an FAQ section from the developer stating that the auto-aim is by design and that it's a "better" way to play the game. Furthermore, they mentioned that they will not be adding the option to aim yourself.

This decision feels like a significant oversight and a missed opportunity. Giving players the freedom to aim would have made the gameplay more engaging and allowed for more strategic choices. Unfortunately, this lack of control ultimately led me to uninstall the game and request a refund.

It's a shame because the game had potential. The visuals are appealing, and the concept is intriguing. However, the frustrating auto-aim mechanics make it difficult to fully enjoy the experience. Unless the developers address this issue, I can't recommend investing time or money into this game.

Welcome to the nonsensical world of "Yet Another Zombie Survival," the game that takes the zombie apocalypse to a whole new level of hilarity! From the moment you step into this wacky, undead-infested realm, you'll find yourself laughing, facepalming, and wondering if the game developers were dropped on their heads as babies. But fear not, because that's precisely what makes this game so delightfully absurd!

Let's address the elephant in the room right away: the lack of content. "Yet Another Zombie Survival" boldly embraces its own mediocrity by providing you with the bare minimum. You'll wander through a seemingly endless expanse of cookie-cutter environments that make the concept of "exploration" feel as exciting as watching paint dry. Seriously, who needs diversity when you can have the same tree repeated a thousand times?

Now, onto the character progression, or rather, the complete lack thereof. Prepare yourself for a journey so linear that it would make a stick look like a complex geometric shape. Your character upgrades are as predictable as a broken record

But hey, amidst all the lackluster content and linear character progression, "Yet Another Zombie Survival" manages to find its charm. It's like a B-movie you can play, with hilariously cheesy dialogue and absurd situations that make you question the sanity of the game designers. It's a game where you can battle zombies with a rubber chicken or launch exploding watermelons at them. Who needs logic when you have watermelon grenades, right?

In conclusion, "Yet Another Zombie Survival" may lack content and offer a character progression system that puts a straight line to shame, but it embraces its flaws and turns them into a comedic experience. It's a game that doesn't take itself seriously, and in turn, encourages you not to take it seriously either. So, if you're in the mood for a mindless, laughter-filled zombie apocalypse romp, grab your sense of humor and join the madness!

Hi devs, I don't know how you managed to make a game where all you do is play keep-away this fun, but you did. The gameplay is super addicting, and this game has absurd amounts of potential.

That said, there are definitely balance issues:

Second-tier Engineer weapons feel underpowered, and while the laser looks satisfying, it doesn't do enough damage to make it useful. The blaster looks less satisfying, but does more damage, though still not enough to warrant investing in if it can be avoided, which it kind of can't. Boost the laser damage a bunch, and slow the blaster balls; they also would benefit from AOE love of some kind.

The third-tier Ninja weapon is... not good. You can barely see it, and you certainly don't see the effects of it. It needs a visual overhaul, and the kunai need to be at least as big as the shuriken, which are also underpowered. A third-tier ability should feel like doom on wheels. 

I haven't unlocked everything, these are just my observations thus far.

Cool game to turn your brain off to. However, definitely doesn't cater to me personally. Which I didn't expect it to. The game describes what it is from the get go before you even buy it and I like that, it's not hiding what it is. However what it is, isn't engaging for me for the most part. I know it's supposed to be just simple, but it's just too simple for me. Don't mistake that as me being an elitist snob; i see how the movement is actually very involved, true to the spirit of bullet hell. As the game progresses, more special enemies will have bigger and harder hitting AOE damage. Squad progression is cool and actually does influence how you move. But all you do is just move. It's not enough for me to be hooked. Honestly if I just had more buttons to play with and more control over my characters and abilities, I could very easily be hooked like everyone else. I wanted to keep my mind open to this type of game as I don't play these types of bullet hell's often (I.E vampire survivors) but it's not for me. If you enjoy turning your brain off and upgrading stuff to be more effective at killing stuff, definitely scratches that itch. I'm leaving a positive because I can definitely see why people will like it, nothing here so far been a big enough negative or abhorrent in design for me to complain about in terms of how the gameplay design is set. They have a solid foundation with stuff to sink your time. It's just the gameplay itself doesn't do it for me. Maybe if the devs decide to include an alternate control scheme for me to have more control over it, but I highly doubt that they'd listen to a very niche complaint like mine. Which they shouldn't honestly. My complaint is probably the only one you'll probably see here compared to everyone else's. Still cool game, interested to see what comes down the pipeline as development continues.

There's many issues to list here:

For a game of this type, the price tag is high and yet it has the least content at the moment it launched in early access of any similar game that I played. There's 1 very small map that takes ~20 sec to run across in a straight line and 6 characters total.

Balancing is bad. Character's weapon can be evolved 2 times. The first evolution is, in my opinion, always a direct upgrade. The final evolution however feels like a downgrade or sidegrade at best in almost every case. Most items unlocked by achievements are garbage and only serve to dilute the selection pool when you pick up the chest. It's quite possible the only game of this type that I played where unlocking achievements feels bad because of that.

When we exclude all the crap that eventually clutters the item selection, we're left with a very barebones selection of items that are actually useful, which again, have balance issues. 10% fire rate and -10% reload time aren't exactly equal. Neither are 5% damage and 5% crit damage.

You have no ability to aim manually, it's only automatic. You WILL die because your characters refuse to shoot at zombies in front of you and instead target randomly. It does prioritize closest enemies, but it's meaningless when you're trying to move, and this game requires you to move to get pickups for level ups and items.

Your hitbox is MASSIVE - significantly larger than the characters you're controlling. This largely removes the skill factor from dodging. Hitbox is too large to get around enemies.

It is early access and the bugs i saw aren't worth mentioning (no crashes) but I would like to highlight two game design issues I have.
1. Your hit box feels too big. I might just be a symptom of the fast zombies snapping 180 to swing at you and the mini boss attacks not being well defined. It was bad enough at low meta progression i considered uninstalling and refunding.
2. The medic feels like crap. Shes the last one you'll probably unlock and her weapon kit gets worse as you level it. Her abilities are a waste of a squad spot because you sacrifice so much damage for healing you've already learned to itemize for prior to unlocking her. She feels this bad because the other 5 characters all feel great. Her weapons need an overhaul and I would like to see her passive heal include an over heal (shield) so its distinct from regen/life steal items.

Basically a vampire survivor style game (auto target, auto fire bullet hell). Which is exactly what I expected as I played the Demo. The concept of using 3 characters with each their own weapons and skills is a nice new take on the genre. Which is definitely it's strongest attribute. In addition it moves away from the fantasy to the zombie modern age style which is also a nice pace of change. 

One of the downsides I encountered though, even though I personally thought it was value for it's money, it does start with rather limited content with only having 1 map and 6 classed for the listed price (10 euros), which is rather steep for a bullet hell with this amount of content. Then again it is still in early access so I see this expanding in to a great game. Right now due to this does get a bit repetitive (mostly the map) as you cannot alternate this. 

Just as a shout out for those that played the other Zombie defender game of the same maker, (great game) this is not the same, there is no base building or wave defending, its just endless waves.

Pro
[list]
[*] 3 man party is new and fun to experiment with
[*] Challenge is at a good level, especially Endless and Hardcore
[*] Interesting classes and ability
[*] Nice graphics
[*] Complimenting classes
[*] Infinite support item pick up! (really like this)
[*] Follows the bullet hell principles well and makes it a fun way to play
[/list]

Cons
[list]
[*] Limited content (at time of review) (1 Map, 6 Classes) 
[*] No ability combos (would be nice to see)
[*] Some glitches with the bosses (super speed after being frozen, sometimes at high difficulty level they teleport etc)
[*] Frustrating rerolls (exactly the same offering, multiple times in a row)
[*] Damage output for some of the "DPS" classes is off. Hope this get balanced more in future updates.
[/list]

Honestly, the game's price does not reflect its real value. Despite being in Early Access, the gameplay on offer is far from promising. The variety of enemies and maps resembles that of a mobile game, which does not bode well for its future potential.

Realistically, it's hard to imagine how they could enhance the gameplay to make it truly attractive. It might entertain you for a couple of hours (I personally spent more time due to my obsession with Steam achievements), but it's just a title you'd let your younger sibling play while you're on the PlayStation.

Despite my reluctance to compare games, I must say that no matter how many updates it gets, I can't see how it could compete with genre stalwarts like Vampire Survivors. In conclusion, this game fails to live up to the expectations set by its price point. There are surely more robust and exciting alternatives available on Steam. I'd advise thinking twice before making this purchase.

Played the demo for this a while ago, like months ago, really enjoyed it. Thought it was a nice peek of what was to come. Now early access is here...and I'm not really sure what they were doing? On top of that it is $10 outside of the launch sale which is a hefty price tag for the bullet heaven/survivor genre. There are plenty of games out there 1/3 or even 1/4 of this price that will provide you with infinitely more fun and content as well as creativity.

What is available right now is bare bones. Outside of just having to grind to unlock characters (I've put 4 hours in literally doing as much focus as I can to unlock the Medic which is to collect an absurd number of health packs), you then have to grind just to get more options for them. Then once you have a character you have to grind just to unlock their full potential (which some of the higher tier guns are just worse than the previous).

It's is definitely one of the games that doesn't respect your time for the lack of content there is right now. It definitely has potential, I like the systems that are there, it just needs more content and some tweaks.

It's unfair to rate this game negatively because of impatient pricks when it's super fun and quite frankly addicting. Be happy that we're going to get future content. I see that as a plus. It's a fun game, the basic loop is good - but it's BASIC, it's a decent and potentially great addition to the genre, but it's also lacking in content, depth, and longevity.  Hence the "potentially" and it IS early access.  One cannot expect every game that hits EA to be nearly bug free and release ready already - some games actually do early access as DEV.  But, since many games DO hit EA in more robust condition, the thumb is sideways for now. (haven't noticed any bugs, myself, btw)

One map, minimal/no build variation, a lot of lackluster weapons/abilities, oddly balanced upgrade tree/pace/something ain't right - generic as can be "trinkets" (yellow chest boons).

Overall one feels like this could be so much more than what it is, and one hopes the game gets there during early access.  If it doesn't, it'll still be a "good" game as it is, I'll just be absolutely, crushingly, devastatingly disappointed.  Sad panda, yo.

"Welcome to the ultimate survival guide for 'Yet Another Zombie Survivors.' This video is your key to mastering the art of survival in a world overrun by the undead.

'Yet Another Zombie Survivors' is a game that pushes your survival instincts to the limit. In this video, we delve into the game's mechanics, from resource gathering to base fortification, and combat strategies.

Whether you're a seasoned survivor or a newcomer to the genre, this video is your survival handbook. We'll explore the game's expansive maps, pinpointing the best locations for resources and safe havens.

Survival isn't just about fighting off zombies - it's about outsmarting them. With the insights from this video, you'll be well on your way to becoming a master survivor.

Don't forget to hit the subscribe button to stay updated on the latest strategies, tips, and updates for 'Yet Another Zombie Survivors.' Together, let's survive the apocalypse!"

Pros:
-Fun systems of 3 teams to build
-Some cool and creative skills
-Pretty cool unlock system and separate meta system
-Decent swarms of mobs and bosses, really feels like a horde.
-unique unlocking requirements for some items makes game play different and challenging.

Cons
-It so bare bones that you'll see more "coming soon" than a theater. 
-No skill transformations. 
-Weapons "level up" can sometimes be into worse forms.
-Life-steal and dodge only viable items, others have too little impact to be worthwhile. 
-Some skills are just bad or worthless. 
-CDs on skills seem excessive vs the dmg or effects they do, weapons do generally better. 
-Some items not explained or just plain worthless. Happiness stat not explained (Seems to affect rate of S.O.S. and item drops). 
-The recent Nerf made it I went from regular clears of normal to not surviving 5 mins. 
-Over all there are better options for cheaper. 

Personally Id say right now give this a pass, let it cook for a while and see what it becomes.

Super solid EA-launch and well worth it even if its a bit barebones in its current state. What's here works very well and you can tell that the devs understand the genre, something that you can't say for many other survivors-games right now. Even if its a bit more expensive than other survivors, its well worth it, and I mean its still very cheap.

This is a arcade-style zombie shooter that's surprisingly very enjoyable due to it's great graphics, flawless and smooth play.  There's no controls other than ASDW to move about, and everything is automated (you don't need to fire, aim or press buttons for special skills etc.... everything just automatically happens periodically).  Some may find this bare-bones, but it greatly simplifies things just like an arcade game.  Though it appears as a team based squad game, the team of 3 are actually clumped together in a group and controlled by the player as if they're a single person.  Its fun adding team mates, but they act as a single player (move around together) but do have different skills and weapons to make different combinations of them interesting.  The enemies are fast and furious, but the variety is limited.   There's small skill trees to unlock and work through.  Very much reminds me of Gauntlet in a lot of ways, but on a single open map.  Great fun and easy to progress through, well worth the low price vs. entertainment factor.  Enjoy!

4.I know being able to manually aim is being added, however it would be nice if you could press 1/2/3 to enable auto targeting per unit!

First off I think the devs are doing an amazing job with this and can't wait to see where they take this game. I like the new additions they've added on and I think it will be amazing when we get a full fledged gameplay experience. For now, its still pretty much a beta game with the one level. But for the $8-$10 your paying you don't get enough to justify the price from the experience you got by just playing the demo version which is one of the biggest drawbacks. You still only get the one level, granted it's only been a few months since then and they probably need to fund the game.

This is a very promising rogue-like filled with zombies that has a lot of potential to be a must own for fans of the genre. One of the biggest critiques I have is that the zombies feel a lot weaker than the demo they had out, but I'm going to give them the benefit of the doubt and say it's because of the S.O.S. beacons and new power ups they've added in and never really compensated the zombies for that. They definitely need some better defense. Bosses are also very weak and boring, just constantly charging at you while being nothing more than a distraction from the rest of the horde following you around. They're supposed to get more dangerous as the level progresses but you basically just delete everything and don't really notice them too much. The additions of power ups and player stats were very nice, the lifesteal could be redone though as I felt I was still getting too much even at 5% when you have a full team of 3 just constantly pumping out dps. Also, removing auto-aim would be nice. 


I recommend this only because I think its going places and the devs are doing a great job. Id love to see more.

Its a refreshing breath of stale air. I don't mean that negatively (even though I'm not recommending the game), they've gone in a different style direction - that includes: gameplay, art style etc. But coming from Halls of Torment to this is a very different experience. Understandably the early release is bare bones, and they aren't bad bones they're just not very thought out bones. I can see this game going in one direction, and its horizontal not vertical. 

Yep by the time it's in full release you'll play for a few hours and go well yeah this is enjoyable but you won't be looking back on it like you did Vampire Survivors, or Halls of Torment, or Swarm Grinder and go "what a great additional to the genre".. it'll just be another additional like all the others that did try and go down a different art style.. but fell flat. 

Again.. I'm not saying don't buy it, you may enjoy it. It is just another watered down reverse bullet-hell clone.

Edit: I'm not refunding the game - I want to see where it is in a 6-12 months time.

I've had my eye on this game for awhile now and thought it would be a great game for the steam deck, so I was excited to try it on day one. The game play is fun and I could see myself putting quite a few hours into it. 

While it is functional out of the box on the steam deck, it does not hold a steady frame rate, often hovering around 22-24 fps only a minute or so into the run. I did turn off the damage numbers & gore as well as set the lighting to minimal to see if that would help keep it locked at 30 fps but no luck. 

I also played it on my lower-mid end desktop and it held 60 fps with no problem so, it seems it is just a power limitation on the steam deck. 

Again the game play seems like a lot of fun but I am undecided if I will keep or refund since I specifically wanted it for the steam deck.

The reverse bullet hell genre has been all the rage for the past couple of years, and by now, the market is crowded with dime-a-dozen copy paste versions, however, on rare occasion, something like Yet Another Zombie Survivors (YAZS) comes through and reminds us why we love this genre so much.

This is a fantastic game with the same formula but provides its own spin in terms of flavor and gameplay. I have been playing the game on my steam deck and haven't been able to put it down, except to recharge the deck occasionally.

The premise of the game is simple. Pick a class and survive the night against hordes of zombies for 20 minutes until daylight. You occasionally get S.O.S signals using which you can recruit a party member and upgrade them as well, instead of doing this solo. Or if you want to do it solo, liberate them and keep going. You also get crates that contain interesting bonuses that help the run. Some of these need balancing without a doubt (looking at you % health bonuses - 3 of these and every health pack heals you for a quarter of your max HP), but it keeps the game fresh and enjoyable, adding an element of randomness. The skills are fun and the weapons have a punch to them. It is satisfying to see the skills and weapons cut through the zombies, accentuated by the ragdoll physics.

Unlike some other games in the genre, there is really no point at which you overpower the game. Until the 20 minute mark, it is a constant battle of skill and speed. This was a refreshing change compared to other games where the first few levels are tough, but once you unlock a few key skills, you can hold down the directional keys with one hand and sip a latte using the other, cruising your way to victory. Here, the game in fact gets harder as time goes on, and the challenge gets higher as you get more powerful, so you are constantly on your toes.

In terms of performance, the game ran smoothly almost throughout each run. Granted, there was a run with a couple of moments when some frames dropped and I experienced a brief stutter, but it was a one-time thing. This didn't happen on any subsequent run though, so overall, it isn't a concern. It is also the perfect game for the steam deck. Pick up and play, pause the game and suspend it if you need to take a break, come back and seamlessly resume your run.

All in all, a solid game in the reverse bullet hell genre that is definitely worth playing.

Yet Another Zombie Survivors is a deceivingly simple but addictive reverse bullet hell game where you and your team have to fight off hordes of zombies with various weapons and abilities. The game is currently in Early Access, but it already offers a lot of fun and challenge for fans of the genre.

The game lets you choose from multiple characters, each with their own special skills and upgrades. You can also customize your weapons and abilities to suit your playstyle and strategy. The game is fast-paced and chaotic, but also rewarding and satisfying when you manage to survive and evolve.

The game has only one level/map so far, but it's well-designed and varied enough to keep you entertained for hours. The graphics are colorful and cartoony, and the sound effects are fitting and immersive. The game also has a meta-progression system that lets you unlock more content and features as you play.

The game is not perfect, of course. It still has some bugs and glitches, and it could use more polish and optimization. The game also lacks some features that would make it more replayable and engaging, such as more maps/environments, more enemy types and variations, additional gameplay modifiers, and a complete meta-progression system.

However, the developers are very responsive and open to feedback from the community. They have a suggestions' forum on their Discord server and a pinned thread on the Steam forum where they listen to players' ideas and opinions. 

Overall, Yet Another Zombie Survivors is a great game for anyone who loves action, roguelike, RPG, or bullet hell games. It's simple but fun, addictive but challenging, and cheap but worth it. If you're looking for a new game to play with your friends or by yourself, give this one a try. You won't regret it.

This comment is written on day 1 of the EA release. Nevertheless, so far, I don´t regret the purchase. It does not really add much to the well estabilshed formula. But what it does, it does pretty well.  What I have not seen in other games so far is the addition of other playable characters with all its perks (during a run) that supports you and can be upgraded just like you can upgrade your own character. So you have more choices of weapons which is always a plus. Also (though highly subjective) I like that this game does not have the typical retro or cartoonish look. For a game at this price point, it really looks pretty good.

So, if you are not tired of the genre yet, I do not see a reason to recommend it. Also, the approach to include the community on the way to the gold status is certainly commendable.
